185668335.review:
[H3] Skyrim’s world is beautifully handcrafted, dense with loot and memorable quests. However, a lack of gameplay progression dulls the excitement of adventuring. [/H3]

Skyrim’s unarguably cemented itself into the canon of gaming history. While I remember initial reactions were more lukewarm, owing to a lack of depth, over the years it’s achieved classic status and has brought millions of new players to the Elder Scrolls franchise. My sister’s lone PS3 game, for example, is a well-spun copy of Skyrim which she’s reached level 20. The game’s easier difficulty to previous entries also means that, despite having challenges with hand-eye coordination due to her cerebral palsy, she’s able to explore and enjoy the game more than any other Bethesda title.

For that, I feel incredibly guilty and contrarian giving Skyrim a negative review. However, for me, I don’t find it a satisfying vanilla experience in 2025. While its outside world is designed with immense precision and an eye for natural beauty, its dungeons follow similar colour palettes and are loaded with repeating textures. Plenty of valuable loot are hidden in them, but that’s also one of the game’s biggest issues: you’re rich within five hours. Necklaces and staffs worth thousands of coins are found near the very beginning of the game, meaning you’re bankrupting every merchant you find almost immediately.

Worst still is the level scaling. Due to the game adapting its difficulty to your level, it feels like all encounters have the same level of challenge. Each fight feels like it’s almost getting difficult but not quite, making them entirely unsurprising. It feels good to play, swords bounce off shields and ragdolls make paralysis spells hilarious to use, but that only takes the game so far. Archery is satisfying when taking shots from afar, yet there are so many invisible walls and geometry for  your arrows to get stuck on. You can tell the environments are blockier than they let on, which unfairly ruins your perfectly aligned stealth shots. 

Builds don’t matter either, as you can max out every skill under one character. This leads to a fundamentally limited roleplaying experience, as there are no real tradeoffs or incentive to make new characters. The game is also [i] still [/i] glitchy: characters spawn on tables, assassins don’t attack, and loading screens can hang. 

Overall, I appreciate what Skyrim has provided to gaming, but the vanilla version is too barebones to be satisfying. For gamers looking to play a couple hours a week, it’s easy to pick up and play. The controls feel great and, crashes aside, the performance is a dream. However, I don’t see myself returning to the game for a long time.

185645551.review:
[h1] The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim 9/10 [/h1]

Released in 2011, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim quickly became a game changing RPG that captured the hearts of millions. With a richly detailed open world, countless quests, and an engaging story, it earned Game of the Year and numerous other awards. The game's modding community continues to breathe new life into Skyrim, keeping it relevant even today. The sheer scope of exploration and customization ensures players can always find something new, from dragon shouts to discovering hidden Easter eggs like the Macho Man Randy Savage shout or the Oblivion references.

Pros:

■ Massive open world filled with lore, side quests, and secrets
■ Deep customization and modding support
■ Memorable characters and locations, like Whiterun and the Throat of the World
■ Stunning visuals for its time (still impressive with mods)

Cons:

■ [b] At the request of the publisher, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is unlisted on the Steam store and will not appear in search [/b]
■ Combat can feel repetitive after a while
■ Some bugs and glitches, though often patched or modded away
■ AI can be clunky in certain situations

The game even inspired some real-world references, like the infamous "Arrow to the Knee" meme, which swept the internet in 2011.

With its lasting legacy, Skyrim remains a beloved classic, and fans are eagerly awaiting The Elder Scrolls VI.

185183048.review:
Ah, Skyrim. The game that refuses to die, much like the dragonborn themselves. First released in 2011, it has since been ported to every platform imaginable—including your toaster, probably. And yet, we’re all still here, ready to shout "Fus Ro Dah" at bandits while stealing every fork, plate, and wheel of cheese in sight.

Let’s talk about the gameplay. Skyrim is what happens when you give players a massive open world and absolutely no sense of moderation. "Go save the world from Alduin, the World-Eater!" they said. But did we listen? No. We were too busy chasing butterflies, adopting children, and somehow ending up the leader of every guild in Tamriel. Seriously, how does the Companions trust you after you "accidentally" decapitated half of Whiterun?

The graphics? Stunning in 2011, still passable in 2024—especially with mods. Oh, the mods. Want to fight Thomas the Tank Engine instead of dragons? Done. Want Macho Man Randy Savage yelling at you from the sky? Also done. Skyrim is less a game and more a platform for chaos. The limit isn’t your imagination; it’s your PC’s ability to run with 400 mods installed.

And then there’s the bugs. Glorious, beautiful bugs. Floating horses, NPCs walking through walls, and your follower getting stuck in a door for the 50th time—it’s all part of the charm. Bethesda didn’t create a flawless masterpiece; they created a sandbox where even the glitches are entertaining.

The soundtrack? Perfection. You’ll be humming the Dragonborn Theme while getting wrecked by a frost troll on the way to High Hrothgar. It’s a rite of passage. The voice acting? Well, let’s just say the same five voice actors are really working overtime. But hey, you’ll never forget lines like “I used to be an adventurer like you, then I took an arrow to the knee.” Iconic.

Skyrim is less about the story (because let’s be honest, who even remembers the main quest?) and more about the experience. It’s a game where you can spend hours picking flowers, crafting iron daggers, and wondering why every guard knows you’re carrying stolen goods. It’s a game where you can literally shout a dragon off a mountain and call it "strategy."

So, should you play Skyrim? Absolutely. It’s a timeless classic that lets you be whoever you want—except someone who actually finishes the main story. Whether you’re a stealth archer (let’s be real, we’re all stealth archers) or a dual-wielding lunatic, Skyrim welcomes you. Just don’t forget to save often—because that frost troll isn’t going to wait. 10/10, would Fus Ro Dah a goat off a cliff again.

185182543.review:
This game dominated my life for a long time and still does in a large way. I have owned this game on every single console, and have owned every single type. I have 161 hours on PC and I do not even want to check other systems. This is single highhandedly one of the greatest games I have every played, and despite my many hundreds of hours playing I still discover new things almost every time I click play. I can not recommend this game more. 

The only negative I believe is that this game has sponsored a relaxed mindset for the developers Bethesda. It has been 6 years since the trailer for the Elder Scrolls 6, we need more information and a release date.

185181357.review:
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim – Ein Meisterwerk, das nie alt wird...

Die Reise begann am 11. November 2011 und ich weiß noch genau, wie die Welt sich veränderte.

Mit einem Schlag veränderte Skyrim die Art und Weise, wie wir Open-World-Rollenspiele erleben. Am 11. November 2011, dem Tag, an dem das Spiel veröffentlicht wurde, wusste ich bereits, dass ich in eine Welt eintauchen würde, die mich über Jahre begleiten sollte. Und tatsächlich, Skyrim bot mir von der ersten Sekunde an ein unvergleichliches Erlebnis. Über 3000 Stunden habe ich in dieser epischen Welt verbracht, habe Drachen bezwungen, Dungeons erkundet, unzählige Quests erledigt und unzählige Charaktere getroffen – und doch, irgendwann kam der Moment, als ich das Gefühl hatte, mich von dieser Welt zu verabschieden.

Ein Abenteuer, das niemals endet

Skyrim ist das, was man einen zeitlosen Klassiker nennt. Die riesige, offene Welt war zu seiner Zeit (und ist auch heute noch) eine der beeindruckendsten in der Geschichte der Videospiele. Das Gefühl, in eine lebendige, atmende Welt einzutauchen, in der jede Entscheidung Konsequenzen hatte, war damals revolutionär. Du wählst deinen eigenen Weg, gehst auf Reisen, baust deine Fähigkeiten aus und erschaffst deinen eigenen legendären Helden – die Freiheit, die du als Spieler hast, ist grenzenlos. Es gab so viele Wege, die Geschichte zu erleben und zu gestalten, dass keine zwei Spielerlebnisse gleich waren.

Die Rückkehr der Drachen war ein faszinierendes Element, das das Spiel noch epischer machte. Als Drachenblut hattest du die Möglichkeit, die geheimnisvollen Kräfte der Drachen zu erlernen und sie in deinem Kampf gegen diese gigantischen Kreaturen einzusetzen. Und wer könnte die legendären Drachenkämpfe vergessen, die sich jedes Mal wie ein einzigartiger, herausfordernder Höhepunkt anfühlten?

Das Spiel, das mich nie loslässt

Es gibt nur wenige Spiele, die so eine tiefe emotionale Bindung zu einem Spieler aufbauen. Skyrim ist eines dieser Spiele. Jedes Mal, wenn ich das Spiel wieder starte, werde ich von der Atmosphäre, den epischen Landschaften und den unzähligen Geschichten, die in der Welt verborgen sind, aufs Neue gefesselt. Die Städte, Dörfer, Wälder und Gebirgspässe sind nicht nur Kulissen, sie fühlen sich lebendig an. Jeder NPC hat seine eigene Geschichte, jede Ecke scheint ein Geheimnis zu verbergen, das darauf wartet, entdeckt zu werden. Skyrim hat etwas, das viele Spiele nicht haben – es ist mehr als nur ein Spiel, es ist eine Welt, in der du wirklich leben kannst.

Doch irgendwann wird auch das Größte alt…

Nach über 3000 Stunden, unzähligen Quests und einer fast endlosen Zahl an Drachen, die ich erledigt habe, begann ich zu merken, dass sich etwas verändert hatte. Vielleicht sind es die Mods, die Skyrim in alle Richtungen erweitern, die das ursprüngliche Gefühl verdrängen. Die Fülle an zusätzlichen Inhalten, die sich irgendwann in der Spielwelt ansammeln, sorgt für eine gewisse Unübersichtlichkeit und lässt mich das Gefühl verlieren, das ich damals zu Beginn hatte. Der Charme des ursprünglichen „Vanilla“-Spiels ging für mich langsam verloren, als ich mich von Mod zu Mod bewegte. Aber auch das ist eine der großen Stärken von Skyrim – die unglaubliche Modding-Community hat dafür gesorgt, dass das Spiel immer wieder in neuem Glanz erstrahlt, auch wenn es mich mittlerweile nicht mehr ganz so fesselt wie zu Beginn.

Das Spiel bleibt ein Meisterwerk, aber der Abschied naht

Was bleibt, wenn man über 3000 Stunden in ein Spiel gesteckt hat? Eine ganze Menge Erinnerungen an epische Kämpfe, die Schönheit von Himmelsrand, die magischen Momente, wenn man zum ersten Mal einen Drachen besiegt oder ein antikes Relikt entdeckt. Es war ein unglaubliches Abenteuer, das so viele Stunden Unterhaltung geboten hat, dass ich keinen einzigen Moment bereue.

Aber irgendwann kommen die Phasen, in denen man das Gefühl hat, das Spiel hinter sich zu lassen. Nicht, weil es schlecht ist, sondern weil man alles gesehen hat, was es zu bieten hat. Ich erinnere mich immer noch an die Musik, die mich in jeder Stadt, jedem Dämmerwald und jeder Höhle begleitet hat. Sie hat immer das gewisse Etwas in mir berührt – das Gefühl von Nostalgie, das mich bis heute verfolgt.

Fazit: Ein absoluter Zeitfresser, aber keiner, den ich bereue.

Skyrim wird für immer ein Meisterwerk der Videospielgeschichte bleiben. Es hat das RPG-Genre revolutioniert und bietet eine offene Welt, die man so schnell nicht wiederfinden wird. Die Freiheit, die dieses Spiel einem lässt, ist einzigartig, und auch nach Jahren bleibt es ein monumentales Erlebnis. Auch wenn ich mich mittlerweile von der Welt verabschiede, werde ich es niemals vergessen. Ein Spiel, das für immer einen besonderen Platz in meinem Herzen hat.

184163555.review:
Skyrim w moich oczach jest grą niezwykle płytką. Zarówno historia, jak i rozgrywka wydają się pozbawione głębi, która mogłaby wciągnąć na dłużej. Fabuła, choć początkowo intrygująca, szybko rozpływa się w morzu pobocznych zadań, które sprowadzają się do schematycznych czynności. Postacie w większości przypadków są jednowymiarowe.

Pod wieloma względami Skyrim przypomina grę-usługę w stylu Counter-Strike'a. Odpala się ją od czasu do czasu, by zrobić jedną konkretną rzecz – powalczyć ze smokiem, ulepszyć zbroję czy zwiedzić podziemia – coś, co jest solidnie zaprojektowane i znajome. Jednak po chwili refleksji nasuwa się pytanie: po co właściwie to robić? Brakuje satysfakcji, poczucia celu czy głębszego sensu w tym, co oferuje ta gra, zwłaszcza że ten CS którego wspominam, oferuje poczucie tego że czegoś się nauczyłem i jestem w tym dobry. To istny symulator generowania pierdołowatych zadań, które się wykonuje bez większego sensu, przy czym aspekt rozwijania swoich umiejętności jako grającego, jest znikomy.

Bardzo doceniam w tej grze tą epickość, którą można zaobserwować w designie świata. Każda z "dzielnic" mapy posiada odmienny klimat przez co oferuje pewną różnorodność. Projekt artystyczny lokacji, muzyka tworząca klimat i umilająca eksplorację to najmocniejsza, obok samej eksploracji i mechaniki nabywania umiejętności poprzez ich ciągłe wykonywanie, zaleta tej gry. 

Gra bardzo się zestarzała pod względem rozgrywki, jednakże nie będę na siłę podważał to że jest to dobra gra. Na pewno nie jest to arcydzieło za które ludzie je uważają, ale patrząc na to że ma ona już prawie 14 lat i conajmniej do 2015 roku nie wychodziła gra warta uwagi będąca fantasy, oraz to że znacząco się ona przyczyniła do rozwoju "Gamingu" ostatnich kilkinastu lat to daję jej 7/10.

PS. Mam nadzieje ze nigdy juz w nią nie zagram xd

184116003.review: A game that definitely stands the test of time and that makes you want to replay it every few years. Probably useless to write this review as of now but definitely an all-time classic.

184077530.review:
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a monumental entry in the fantasy role-playing genre, celebrated for its vast open world and immersive gameplay. Released by Bethesda in 2011, it invites players to explore the frigid province of Skyrim, where they assume the role of the Dragonborn, a hero destined to confront the return of ancient dragons.

## Gameplay and Exploration
Skyrim excels in offering players unparalleled freedom. The game features a richly detailed environment filled with hundreds of quests and countless opportunities for exploration. Players can engage in various activities, from combat to crafting, and can develop their characters in multiple ways without being confined to traditional class systems. This flexibility allows for a personalized gaming experience, where one can be a warrior, mage, or a hybrid of both, enhancing replayability[1][4].

## Story and Quests
The central narrative revolves around the Dragonborn's quest to uncover the mystery behind the dragons' resurgence. While the main storyline is compelling, many players find that the side quests and character interactions provide equally engaging experiences. The game’s world feels alive; NPCs have daily routines, and their interactions contribute to a deeper immersion in the lore and culture of Skyrim[3][4].

## Visuals and Technical Aspects
Visually, Skyrim showcases Bethesda's Creation Engine, which delivers stunning landscapes and intricate details that make exploration rewarding. Although some technical flaws exist, such as occasional bugs and performance issues, they do little to detract from the overall experience. The game's art style complements its fantasy setting beautifully[2][3].

## Conclusion
In summary, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is not just a game but an expansive playground that offers a blend of rich storytelling, deep character customization, and breathtaking exploration. Its ability to allow players to craft their own unique adventures makes it an essential experience for any RPG enthusiast. Despite minor imperfections, its achievements in world-building and player agency solidify its status as a modern classic in gaming history[1][2].

Citations:
[1] https://www.giantbomb.com/reviews/the-elder-scrolls-v-skyrim-review/1900-443/
[2] https://www.iceflatline.com/2012/03/a-quick-review-of-the-elder-scrolls-v-skyrim-for-pc/
[3] https://www.eurogamer.net/the-elder-scrolls-5-skyrim-review
[4] https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1814884/reviews/

183738956.review:
Classic medieval fantasy that will never die.

[b][u] STORY - 7/10[/u][/b]
Straight forward narrative of the main quests where much better stories are told through the major side-quests (Thieves Guild is the best of the lot). However, much of the side cast is plain, boring or just one-dimensional with some rare exceptions like Alduin, Parthenaax & Jarl Ulric. 

[b][u] GAMEPLAY - 6/10[/u][/b]
Simple, straight forward, but still extremely outdated even for its time. I mostly enjoy the concept of its leveling system of the more you do something, the better you become at it. As well as the freedom in gameplay where there is no limitation to your build. Dungeons are extremely grindy and boring after a while and even the Shouts end up mostly being defaulted with Fus Ra Da.

[b][u] VISUALS - 6/10[/u][/b]
Fairly outdated visuals unless you mod the crap out of it. Easiliy the weakest aspect of this game and don't even get me started on the number of bugs and glitches I've come across (which actually makes this game more fun for some reason :/ ).

[b][u] MUSIC - 8/10[/u][/b]
Iconic soundtrack that gets my blood pumping.

[b][u] EXTRA: MODS - 10/10[/u][/b]
This is the reason this game never died. The fact its modding community is still going strong speaks for itself and in truth, its recommended to play this game with a ton of mods installed for the best experience. It is also why I keep finding myself coming back.

[b][u] OVERALL - 7.4/10[/u][/b]
If any game deserves the title of Classic, its this game just entirely based on the strong modding community and the fact that Bethesda just won't let it die much like GTA V.

I got it and still play it for the great story and how the graphics changed at the time. I love the side missions still and have let my sons mod it and now i have to play it through how they set it up. I'm going to take over Skyrim and become the new Highking of Skyrim. I still recommend this game all these years later.

183518914.review: This is a fantastic game with one of the largest modding communities out there. I would highly recommend it for its versatility and depth. Nearly endless run potential. Probably my favorite game of all time.

183511752.review:
A game where you can save the world, steal every sweet roll in existence, and Fus Ro Dah a bandit off a cliff, all before breakfast. It’s the ultimate fantasy RPG, where the only limit is your imagination—or, more accurately, the 5,000 mods you’ve downloaded hoping the last one of which doesn't brick your game.

The true Skyrim experience begins the moment you discover mods. Why settle for regular dragons when you can replace them with Macho Man Randy Savage, screaming “OH YEAH” as they barrel through the sky? Why have a boring, standard-issue horse when you can ride Thomas the Tank Engine into battle? Bethesda may have built the framework, but modders turned it into a masterpiece.

Want to crank the immersion up to 11? Download a survival mod that makes you eat, sleep, and freeze to death if you forget to pack socks. Want to turn every NPC into a Shrek lookalike? There’s a mod for that, too. 

And don’t even get me started on the graphics mods. By the time you’re done installing ENBs and 8K textures, Skyrim looks so beautiful it makes real life feel like a low-res cutscene. Sure, your PC might sound like it’s trying to launch itself into orbit, but who cares? You’ve got ray-traced lighting and NPCs with pores more detailed than your actual face.

10/10. Would spend more time modding than actually playing again.
